MDMA

Timeline

by Erowid

1898 Some claim that Fritz Haber was the first to publish a synthesis for MDMA, but this appears not to the case. 1 , 2 [Details] Haber's doctoral thesis "Uber einige Derivate des Piperonals" ['about a few piperonal derivatives'] for Friedrich-Wilhelms University of Berlin, described related syntheses, but does not include MDMA.  Although this was a small controversy in the early 2000's, you can read our more recent understanding of this issue in Ask Erowid . 1912 MDMA first synthesized by Anton Köllisch and patented by Merck Pharmaceuticals in Germany. [Details] [More Info] Merck synthesized MDMA as a precursor during their investigation into haemostatic substances (not as an appetite suppressant as has been rumored).


                    Context: 
                    This chunk introduces the MDMA Timeline section from Erowid’s MDMA (Ecstasy) reference page, outlining the origins, synthesis, and early history of MDMA—including common misconceptions, its first synthesis by Anton Köllisch at Merck in 1912, and the context of its early chemical research. It follows a brief call for book donations and marks the start of a detailed chronological account of MDMA’s development, research milestones, and cultural significance.

                    It is believed that Merck never went on to use MDMA for any purpose. After World War I, Merck's US unit was confiscated.  The company most people know today as Merck is no longer affiliated with Merck (KGaA) of Germany.  However at the time of the original MDMA patent, Merck was a single company. 1927 Merck chemist Max Oberlin conducts the first animal testing with MDMA while investigating 'adrenaline- or ephetonine-like' substances. 3 1953 The Army Chemical Center studied MDMA toxicity by giving MDMA to guinea pigs, rats, mice, monkeys, and dogs.  It is determined to be less toxic than MDA. 4 1965 Alexander Shulgin synthesizes MDMA but does not yet try it. 5 1967-1970 The first small underground batches of MDMA are synthesized. Some, but relatively few individuals have tried it at this point. 6 [Details] Erowid does not currently have clear documentation about when the first recreational use of MDMA occurred. Although some references indicate pre-1970, we do not have clear evidence


                    Context:

This section helps establish the historical emergence of MDMA as a recreational drug.

                    Text: 
                    Class A is the most controlled category of drugs in Britain. 1978 First scholarly characterization of MDMA is published. 11 [Details] A second compound to be described in this presentation is the N-methyl homolog of a well studied psychotomimetic, 3,4-methyleneioxyphenylisopropylamine (MDA, 5). As with MDA, MDMA (chemically properly N-methyl-3,4-methylenedioxyphenylisopropylamine or 1-(3 ,4- methylenedioxyphenyl)-2-(methylamino)-propane) has the aromatic substitution pattern of the essential oil safrole (6) from which it was first synthesized in 1960 (Ref. 8). The only toxicological and behavioral report involving this compound was an Army Chemical Center study performed in the 1950’s, declassified in 1967, and published in 1973 (Ref. 9). There are no reports concerning its psychopharmacological action in man, although the compound has had occasional and erratic appearance in the illicit Street drug market (Ref. 10). For this reason, if for no other, it falls under the purview of the

It follows discussion of Britain's 1977 legislative scheduling of MDMA as a Class A drug and provides scientific background on MDMA's chemical relation to MDA, its synthesis from safrole, and the lack of human psychopharmacological studies at that time. The chunk is part of a chronological account documenting key legal, scientific, and cultural milestones in the development, research, regulation, and use of MDMA.

Feb 2, 2001 The State of Ecstasy: The Medicine, Science and Culture of MDMA [Details] [More Info] Held at The Golden Gate Club, Presidio of San Francisco, CA, and produced by the Drug Policy Alliance, at this event Rick Doblin boldly announced MAPS' "Five Years, Five Million Dollars" plan to turn MDMA into a prescription medicine. Other presenters at the conference included Katherine Bonson, Jose Carlos Bouso, John Cloud, George Greer, Charles S. Grob, Steve Heilig, Jessica Malberg, Ethan Nadelmann, David Nichols, Dustianne North, Marcela Ot'alora, George Ricaurte, Marsha Rosenbaum, Emanuel Sferios, Alexander Shulgin, Ann Shulgin, and Sue Stevens. The purpose of this conference was to objectively present what is known about MDMA with respect to its clinical and therapeutic uses, scientific research into potential neurotoxicity, and the culture of ecstasy, including recreational use and raves.
